title: Should movie titles be italicized? What about TV shows? - Quora

response.answer_text: TV shows - italics (Game of Thrones) - this is true even when you’re using the show as an adjective to describe its fans (what kind of fans? Game of Thrones fans) Full-length books, or series of books - italics (A Song of Ice and Fire); the same is true for book-length collections of different writings, whether by one or multiple authors (Dangerous Visions, edited by Harlan Ellison; The Norton Anthology of English Literature; The Complete Edgar Allan Poe) Book-length single poems - italics (Beowulf; Pearl) Full-length plays, movies, and musicals - italics (Romeo and Juliet; West Side Story; The Lion King) Single poems shorter than book-length - quotation marks (“The Road Not Taken”) Short stories, newspaper articles, magazine articles, blog post titles, essays - quotation marks (“The Ransom of Red Chief”) One episode of a TV show - quotation marks (the Star Trek episode “Encounter at Farpoint”) Name of a newspaper or magazine - italics (The New York Times; People) I’ve honestly seen blog titles go both ways if you’re talking about the whole blog. There are some that would seem really pretentious if you put them in italics, so you can just rewrite the sentence to skip the title. (The doctor who blogs under the pseudonym “Doc Bastard” has gone on record in favor of vaccinations….) For vlogs or other YouTube channels, I don’t think most people will care whether you put the channel title in italics, as long as you put the episode title in quotation marks and italicize anything in that title that needs it. (CinemaSins, in “Everything Wrong With Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones,” claimed…) This is how most styles will do it in most cases for US English. Commonwealth English may have differences.

This is a question I had to deal with in Writing my book, Making Documentary Films and Videos. As a matter of style, I decided:  To treat film titles the same as book titles and italicize them.To treat the names of TV series the same as the names of magazines and italicize them.To treat the titles of individual episodes of a TV series the same as stories or articles in a magazine and place them in quotes.A film, such as Man on Wire, is italicized. A series, such as Nova, is italicized. A single episode from the series Nova, such as "The Sinking City of Venice," is placed in quotation marks. It's not perfect, but it's consistent.
